Decentralized Federated Learning via
Non-Coherent Over-the-Air Consensus

Nicolò Michelusi N. Michelusi is with the School of Electrical, Computer and Energy Engineering, Arizona State University.An extended version of this work appears in [1].This research has been funded in part by NSF under grant CNS-2129615.
Abstract

This paper presents NCOTA-DGD, a Decentralized Gradient Descent (DGD) algorithm that combines local gradient descent with a novel Non-Coherent Over-The-Air (NCOTA) consensus scheme to solve distributed machine-learning problems over wirelessly-connected systems. NCOTA-DGD leverages the waveform superposition properties of the wireless channels: it enables simultaneous transmissions under half-duplex constraints, by mapping local optimization signals to a mixture of preamble sequences, and consensus via non-coherent combining at the receivers. NCOTA-DGD operates without channel state information at transmitters and receivers, and leverages the average channel pathloss to mix signals, without explicit knowledge of the mixing weights (typically known in consensus-based optimization algorithms). It is shown both theoretically and numerically that, for smooth and strongly-convex problems with fixed consensus and learning stepsizes, the updates of NCOTA-DGD converge in Euclidean distance to the global optimum with rate 𝒪​(K−1/4)𝒪superscript𝐾14\mathcal{O}(K^{-1/4}) for a target of K𝐾K iterations. NCOTA-DGD is evaluated numerically over a logistic regression problem, showing faster convergence vis-à-vis running time than implementations of the classical DGD algorithm over digital and analog orthogonal channels.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [2] has emerged as a new paradigm to alleviate the communication burden and privacy concerns associated with the transmission of raw data to a ML server, by leveraging decentralized computational and communication resources at the edge of the network. Typically, it aims to solve

𝐰∗=arg​min𝐰∈ℝd⁡F​(𝐰)≜1N​∑i=1Nfi​(𝐰)superscript𝐰subscriptargmin𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑𝐹𝐰≜1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰\displaystyle{\mathbf{w}}^{*}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\ F(\mathbf{w})\triangleq\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(\mathbf{w}) (P)

among N𝑁N edge devices, where fi​(𝐰)subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰f_{i}(\mathbf{w}) is the empirical loss based on the local dataset of node i𝑖i (known to i𝑖i alone), and 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} is a d𝑑d-dimensional parameter vector, so that F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F(\mathbf{w}) represents the empirical loss over the network. Conventional FL solves (P) based on a client-server architecture, where the N𝑁N nodes interact with a parameter server (PS, such as a base station) over multiple rounds [3]: in each round, edge devices compute local gradients based on a global model broadcast by the PS, and transmit them to the PS; the latter aggregates the local gradients and updates the global model via gradient descent.

Yet, in many important scenarios, a PS may be lacking [4], or direct communication with the PS may be challenging due to severe channel propagation conditions. In these cases, a decentralized learning architecture may be more attractive, in which the edge devices communicate with each other without the aid of a PS [4]. A renowned algorithm to solve (P) in this setting is Decentralized Gradient Descent (DGD) [5]: at iteration k𝑘k, each node (i𝑖i) updates its local optimization signal 𝐰i,ksubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\mathbf{w}_{i,k} by combining a consensus signal 𝐜i,ksubscript𝐜𝑖𝑘\mathbf{c}_{i,k} (weighted sum of the neighbors’ signals) with a local gradient step, as

𝐰i,k+1subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘1\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{i,k+1} =𝐰i,k+∑j=1Nωi,j​(𝐰j,k−𝐰i,k)⏟≜𝐜i,k−η​∇fi​(𝐰i,k);absentsubscript⏟subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝜔𝑖𝑗subscript𝐰𝑗𝑘subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘≜absentsubscript𝐜𝑖𝑘𝜂∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\displaystyle=\underbrace{\mathbf{w}_{i,k}+\sum_{j=1}^{N}\omega_{i,j}(\mathbf{w}_{j,k}-\mathbf{w}_{i,k})}_{\triangleq\mathbf{c}_{i,k}}-\eta\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i,k}); (1)

here, ωi,jsubscript𝜔𝑖𝑗\omega_{i,j} are non-negative mixing weights with ωi,j=ωj,isubscript𝜔𝑖𝑗subscript𝜔𝑗𝑖\omega_{i,j}{=}\omega_{j,i} and ∑j=1Nωi,j=1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝜔𝑖𝑗1\sum_{j=1}^{N}\omega_{i,j}{=}1 (ωi,j=0subscript𝜔𝑖𝑗0\omega_{i,j}{=}0 if i𝑖i and j𝑗j do not communicate directly).

Nevertheless, (1) relies on communications over orthogonal, noise- and error-free links, and on knowledge of the mixing weights to aggregate the incoming signals. In many practical scenarios (e.g., swarms of UAVs), communications occur over wireless links: interference from simultaneous transmissions, fading and noise may preclude the ability to receive error-free signals. Mitigating these sources of errors typically requires: 1) centralized coordination of network scheduling and interference management operations; 2) channel state information (CSI) to compensate signal fluctuations and link outages due to fading. Yet, such coordination may be non-trivial in wireless decentralized systems, and CSI acquisition may be impaired by pilot contamination and a source of severe overhead.

This calls for the design of decentralized optimization schemes that operate over (and leverage properties of) wireless channels. In this paper, we present NCOTA-DGD, an implementation of (1) over wireless channels subject to noise, fading, and interference. Its main feature is a Non-Coherent (NC)-Over-the-Air (OTA) consensus step that leverages the waveform superposition properties of the wireless channels, without the need for CSI at transmitters and receivers, and without explicit knowledge of the mixing weights. We show theoretically and numerically that, for smooth and strongly-convex problems with suitable constant consensus and learning stepsizes, the error (Euclidean distance) between the local models and the solution of (P) converges to zero with rate 𝒪​(K−1/4)𝒪superscript𝐾14\mathcal{O}(K^{-1/4}) for a target of K𝐾K iterations.

Recent OTA-based schemes under client-server [6, 7, 8, 9, 10] and decentralized [11, 12, 13] FL rely on accurate CSI and careful power control to compensate signal fluctuations due to fading. Focusing on decentralized FL, the works [11, 12, 13] use graph coloring to break down the network into smaller non-interfering subgraphs, in which one device operates as the PS. This expedient enables the use of techniques developed for client-server FL (including channel inversion) coupled with a suitable consensus enforcing step. Yet, these schemes rely on CSI and power control to invert channels, scheduling operations (e.g., graph coloring), and knowledge of the network structure and mixing weights ωi,jsubscript𝜔𝑖𝑗\omega_{i,j} for consensus. In contrast, NCOTA-DGD overcomes this need by using a set of orthogonal preamble sequences to encode signals, coupled with non-coherent combining at the receivers; it leverages the channel pathloss to mix signals, without explicit knowledge of the mixing weights. The paper [14] studies consensus over a shared multipath channel. While it assumes the channels to be noiseless and static, our work focuses on decentralized optimization over noisy, time-varying fading channels.

The preamble-based technique developed in this paper is inspired by the preamble-based random access scheme developed in [15] to encode local gradients in client-server FL. The scheme therein relies on noise-free downlink and inversion of the average pathloss at the transmitters. Differently from [15]: 1) NCOTA-DGD operates in decentralized settings, with all links subject to fading and noise; 2) instead of random access-based preamble selection of [15], NCOTA-DGD maps local signals deterministically to a suitable linear combination of preamble sequences; 3) rather than inverting channels, NCOTA-DGD  leverages the average pathloss to mix signals.

This paper is organized as follows. In Sec. II, we describe NCOTA-DGD, followed by its convergence analysis in Sec. III. In Sec. IV, we present numerical results, followed by concluding remarks in Sec. V. An extended version of this work appears in [1], including complete proofs, a more general and non-trivial analysis with decreasing stepsizes, more general fading models and frequency selective channels, stochastic gradient descent updates and extensive numerical evaluations.

Notation: All vectors are in column form. For vector 𝐚𝐚\mathbf{a} (boldface), [𝐚]isubscriptdelimited-[]𝐚𝑖[\mathbf{a}]_{i} is its i𝑖ith component, and ‖𝐚‖=𝐚H​𝐚norm𝐚superscript𝐚H𝐚\|\mathbf{a}\|{=}\sqrt{\mathbf{a}^{\mathrm{H}}\mathbf{a}} its Euclidean norm. II System Model and NCOTA-DGD

We consider N𝑁N wirelessly-connected edge devices, solving (P) via a noisy version of DGD in (1). We assume that the optimizer of (P), 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*}, lies in a d𝑑d-dimensional sphere 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} of radius R𝑅R, within which the optimization is restricted (without loss of generality, centered at 𝟎0\mathbf{0}). For instance, for strongly-convex F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) with strong-convexity parameter μ𝜇\mu, as assumed in the convergence analysis of Sec. III, since ∇F​(𝐰∗)=𝟎∇𝐹superscript𝐰0\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{*}){=}\mathbf{0}, it holds ‖∇F​(𝟎)‖=‖∇F​(𝟎)−∇F​(𝐰∗)‖≥μ​‖𝟎−𝐰∗‖norm∇𝐹0norm∇𝐹0∇𝐹superscript𝐰𝜇norm0superscript𝐰\|\nabla F(\mathbf{0})\|{=}\|\nabla F(\mathbf{0}){-}\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\|{\geq}\mu\|\mathbf{0}{-}\mathbf{w}^{*}\|, hence 𝒲≡{𝐰∈ℝd:‖𝐰‖≤R}𝒲conditional-set𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑norm𝐰𝑅\mathcal{W}{\equiv}\{\mathbf{w}{\in}\mathbb{R}^{d}{:}\|\mathbf{w}\|{\leq}R\}, where R≜1μ​‖∇F​(𝟎)‖≜𝑅1𝜇norm∇𝐹0R{\triangleq}\frac{1}{\mu}\|\nabla F(\mathbf{0})\| may be initially estimated via a consensus phase.

To solve (P) iteratively, we divide time into frames of fixed duration T𝑇T. In frame k𝑘k, node i𝑖i generates the transmission signal 𝐱i,ksubscript𝐱𝑖𝑘\mathbf{x}_{i,k} using the Preamble-based Encoding procedure of Sec. II-A, and transmits it over the wireless channel. Upon receiving the signal from the other nodes in the network (Sec. II-B), it then computes a consensus signal using the Non-Coherent Over-the-Air procedure of Sec. II-C; finally, it updates the local optimization variable by combining the consensus signal with local gradient descent (Sec. II-D). Due to randomness of noise and fading, this procedure induces a stochastic process defined on a proper probability space; we denote by ℱksubscriptℱ𝑘\mathcal{F}_{k} the σ𝜎\sigma-algebra consisting of all signals generated up to frame k𝑘k excluded, along with 𝐰i,ksubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\mathbf{w}_{i,k}.

II-A Preamble-based Encoding

Let 𝒵≡{𝐳m∈ℝd:m=1,…,M}𝒵conditional-setsubscript𝐳𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑𝑚1…𝑀\mathcal{Z}{\equiv}\{\mathbf{z}_{m}{\in}\mathbb{R}^{d}{:}m{=}1,\dots,M\} be a codebook of M=d+1𝑀𝑑1M{=}d{+}1 codewords and 𝐙=[𝐳1,…,𝐳M]𝐙subscript𝐳1…subscript𝐳𝑀\mathbf{Z}=[\mathbf{z}_{1},\dots,\mathbf{z}_{M}] be the d×M𝑑𝑀d{\times}M matrix with m𝑚mth column equal to 𝐳msubscript𝐳𝑚\mathbf{z}_{m}. These are defined as 𝐳d+1=−R​𝟏subscript𝐳𝑑1𝑅1\mathbf{z}_{d+1}{=}-R\mathbf{1} and 𝐳m=2​R​d​𝐞m−R​𝟏,m=1,…,dformulae-sequencesubscript𝐳𝑚2𝑅𝑑subscript𝐞𝑚𝑅1𝑚1…𝑑\mathbf{z}_{m}{=}2Rd\mathbf{e}_{m}{-}R\mathbf{1},m=1,\dots,d. With this choice, any 𝐰∈𝒲𝐰𝒲\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W} may be represented as a convex combination of 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}. To see this, define the convex combination vector 𝐩∈ℝM𝐩superscriptℝ𝑀\mathbf{p}\in\mathbb{R}^{M} as

[𝐩]m=[𝐰]m+R2​R​d,∀m=1,…,d,[𝐩]d+1=1−∑m=1d[𝐩]m.formulae-sequencesubscriptdelimited-[]𝐩𝑚subscriptdelimited-[]𝐰𝑚𝑅2𝑅𝑑formulae-sequencefor-all𝑚1…𝑑subscriptdelimited-[]𝐩𝑑11superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑑subscriptdelimited-[]𝐩𝑚\displaystyle[\mathbf{p}]_{m}{=}\frac{[\mathbf{w}]_{m}{+}R}{2Rd},\forall m=1,\dots,d,\ [\mathbf{p}]_{d+1}{=}1{-}\sum_{m=1}^{d}[\mathbf{p}]_{m}. (2)

Since 𝐰∈𝒲𝐰𝒲\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W} (i.e., ‖𝐰‖≤Rnorm𝐰𝑅\|\mathbf{w}\|{\leq}R and [𝐰]m∈[−R,R]subscriptdelimited-[]𝐰𝑚𝑅𝑅[\mathbf{w}]_{m}{\in}[-R,R]), it is straightforward to see that 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p} takes value from the M𝑀M-dimensional probability simplex, i.e. 𝟏⊤​𝐩=1superscript1top𝐩1\mathbf{1}^{\top}\mathbf{p}=1 and [𝐩]m≥0,∀msubscriptdelimited-[]𝐩𝑚0for-all𝑚[\mathbf{p}]_{m}\geq 0,\forall m, and

𝐰=∑m=1M[𝐩]m​𝐳m=𝐙⋅𝐩.𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscriptdelimited-[]𝐩𝑚subscript𝐳𝑚⋅𝐙𝐩\displaystyle\mathbf{w}=\sum_{m=1}^{M}[\mathbf{p}]_{m}\mathbf{z}_{m}=\mathbf{Z}\cdot\mathbf{p}. (3)

Hence, 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p} in (2) defines the desired convex combination.

Let 𝒰={𝐮m∈ℂM:m=1,…,M}𝒰conditional-setsubscript𝐮𝑚superscriptℂ𝑀𝑚1…𝑀\mathcal{U}{=}\{\mathbf{u}_{m}{\in}\mathbb{C}^{M}:m{=}1,\dots,M\} be a set of M𝑀M orthogonal preamble sequences, defined as 𝐮m=M​𝐞msubscript𝐮𝑚𝑀subscript𝐞𝑚\mathbf{u}_{m}{=}\sqrt{M}\mathbf{e}_{m}. Then, given its local optimization signal 𝐰i,ksubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\mathbf{w}_{i,k}, node i𝑖i generates the convex combination vector 𝐩i,ksubscript𝐩𝑖𝑘\mathbf{p}_{i,k} via (2), and the transmission signal

𝐱i,k=E​∑m=1M[𝐩i,k]m​𝐮m,subscript𝐱𝑖𝑘𝐸superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐩𝑖𝑘𝑚subscript𝐮𝑚\displaystyle\mathbf{x}_{i,k}=\sqrt{E}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\sqrt{[\mathbf{p}_{i,k}]_{m}}\mathbf{u}_{m}, (4)

with average energy per sample E=‖𝐱i,k‖2/M𝐸superscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑘2𝑀E=\|\mathbf{x}_{i,k}\|^{2}/M.

II-B Transmission over the wireless channel

Each node then transmits its signal 𝐱i,ksubscript𝐱𝑖𝑘\mathbf{x}_{i,k} over the wireless channel. We assume Rayleigh flat fading channels hi,jk∼𝒞​𝒩​(0,Λi,j)similar-tosuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑗𝑘𝒞𝒩0subscriptΛ𝑖𝑗h_{i,j}^{k}\sim\mathcal{CN}(0,\Lambda_{i,j}) between transmitting node j𝑗j and receiving node i𝑖i in frame k𝑘k, where Λi,jsubscriptΛ𝑖𝑗\Lambda_{i,j} is the large-scale pathloss. We assume Λi,j=Λj,isubscriptΛ𝑖𝑗subscriptΛ𝑗𝑖\Lambda_{i,j}=\Lambda_{j,i} (channel reciprocity). Furthermore, hi,jksuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑗𝑘h_{i,j}^{k} is i.i.d. over k𝑘k, and independent across i𝑖i-j𝑗j.

We assume that the nodes operate under a half-duplex constraint. We thus divide each frame of duration T𝑇T into 222 slots; each node is assigned to transmit in only one of the 222 slots, and operates in receive mode in the other slot. This assignment is kept fixed during the entire optimization session, and may be done randomly by each node. Let 𝒩isubscript𝒩𝑖\mathcal{N}_{i} be the set of nodes that transmit when node i𝑖i is in receive mode. Node i𝑖i thus receives the signal

where 𝐧i,k∼𝒞​𝒩​(𝟎,σ2​𝐈M)similar-tosubscript𝐧𝑖𝑘𝒞𝒩0superscript𝜎2subscript𝐈𝑀\mathbf{n}_{i,k}{\sim}\mathcal{CN}(\mathbf{0},\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I}_{M}) is AWGN noise with variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}. 𝐲i,ksubscript𝐲𝑖𝑘\mathbf{y}_{i,k} is then correlated with the M𝑀M preamble sequences as

ri,mk=𝐮mH​𝐲i,kE​‖𝐮m‖2=∑j∈𝒩ihi,jk​[𝐩j,k]m+ni,mk;superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐮𝑚Hsubscript𝐲𝑖𝑘𝐸superscriptnormsubscript𝐮𝑚2subscript𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑗𝑘subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐩𝑗𝑘𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖𝑚𝑘\displaystyle r_{i,m}^{k}=\frac{\mathbf{u}_{m}^{\mathrm{H}}\mathbf{y}_{i,k}}{\sqrt{E}\|\mathbf{u}_{m}\|^{2}}=\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}h_{i,j}^{k}\sqrt{[\mathbf{p}_{j,k}]_{m}}+n_{i,m}^{k}; (6)

ni,mk≜𝐮mH​𝐧i,k/(E​‖𝐮m‖2)∼𝒞​𝒩​(0,σ2/(M⋅E))≜superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐮𝑚Hsubscript𝐧𝑖𝑘𝐸superscriptnormsubscript𝐮𝑚2similar-to𝒞𝒩0superscript𝜎2⋅𝑀𝐸n_{i,m}^{k}\triangleq\mathbf{u}_{m}^{\mathrm{H}}\mathbf{n}_{i,k}/(\sqrt{E}\|\mathbf{u}_{m}\|^{2})\sim\mathcal{CN}(0,\sigma^{2}/(M\cdot E)) is the equivalent noise, i.i.d. over i,k,m𝑖𝑘𝑚i,k,m, due to the orthogonality of preamble sequences. Since hi,jk∼𝒞​𝒩​(0,Λi,j)similar-tosuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑗𝑘𝒞𝒩0subscriptΛ𝑖𝑗h_{i,j}^{k}\sim\mathcal{CN}(0,\Lambda_{i,j}), one can see that |ri,mk|2|ℱkconditionalsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑚𝑘2subscriptℱ𝑘|r_{i,m}^{k}|^{2}|\mathcal{F}_{k} has exponential distribution with mean

𝔼​[|ri,mk|2|ℱk]=∑j∈𝒩iΛi,j​[𝐩j,k]m+σ2M⋅E,𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑚𝑘2subscriptℱ𝑘subscript𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖subscriptΛ𝑖𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐩𝑗𝑘𝑚superscript𝜎2⋅𝑀𝐸\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[|r_{i,m}^{k}|^{2}|\mathcal{F}_{k}]=\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}\Lambda_{i,j}[\mathbf{p}_{j,k}]_{m}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{M\cdot E}, (7)

a fact exploited to build the consensus signal in the next step.

II-C Non-Coherent Over-the-Air Consensus

At the end of frame k𝑘k, node i𝑖i computes the consensus signal

𝐝i,k=∑m=1M(|ri,mk|2−σ2M⋅E)​(𝐳m−𝐰i,k).subscript𝐝𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑚𝑘2superscript𝜎2⋅𝑀𝐸subscript𝐳𝑚subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{d}_{i,k}=\sum_{m=1}^{M}\Big{(}|r_{i,m}^{k}|^{2}-\frac{\sigma^{2}}{M\cdot E}\Big{)}(\mathbf{z}_{m}-{\mathbf{w}}_{i,k}). (8)

Using (7), it is straightforward to see that

𝔼​[𝐝i,k|ℱk]=∑j∈𝒩iΛi,j​∑m=1M[𝐩j,k]m​(𝐳m−𝐰i,k).𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝐝𝑖𝑘subscriptℱ𝑘subscript𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖subscriptΛ𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐩𝑗𝑘𝑚subscript𝐳𝑚subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[{\mathbf{d}}_{i,k}|\mathcal{F}_{k}]=\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}\Lambda_{i,j}\sum_{m=1}^{M}[\mathbf{p}_{j,k}]_{m}(\mathbf{z}_{m}-{\mathbf{w}}_{i,k}). (9)

Furthermore, let Λ∗≜maxi​∑j∈𝒩iΛi,j,≜superscriptΛsubscript𝑖subscript𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖subscriptΛ𝑖𝑗\Lambda^{*}{\triangleq}\max_{i}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}\Lambda_{i,j}, and define the mixing weights ωi,j=Λi,jΛ∗⋅𝟙​[j∈𝒩i]subscript𝜔𝑖𝑗⋅subscriptΛ𝑖𝑗superscriptΛ1delimited-[]𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖\omega_{i,j}{=}\frac{\Lambda_{i,j}}{\Lambda^{*}}{\cdot}\mathbbm{1}[j{\in}\mathcal{N}_{i}] for i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j and ωi,i=1−∑j≠iωi,jsubscript𝜔𝑖𝑖1subscript𝑗𝑖subscript𝜔𝑖𝑗\omega_{i,i}=1-\sum_{j\neq i}\omega_{i,j}. Using (3), we can then rewrite (9) as

𝔼​[𝐝i,k|ℱk]=Λ∗​∑j=1Nωi,j​(𝐰j,k−𝐰i,k).𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝐝𝑖𝑘subscriptℱ𝑘superscriptΛsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝜔𝑖𝑗subscript𝐰𝑗𝑘subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[{\mathbf{d}}_{i,k}|\mathcal{F}_{k}]=\Lambda^{*}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\omega_{i,j}(\mathbf{w}_{j,k}-{\mathbf{w}}_{i,k}). (10)

We can see that 𝐝i,ksubscript𝐝𝑖𝑘\mathbf{d}_{i,k} represents a noisy consensus signal reminiscent of (1), which aggregates and averages the local signals of all the other nodes in the network, with mixing weights ωi,jsubscript𝜔𝑖𝑗\omega_{i,j} proportional to the average pathloss Λi,jsubscriptΛ𝑖𝑗\Lambda_{i,j}.

II-D Local optimization state update

Finally, node i𝑖i updates 𝐰i,ksubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\mathbf{w}_{i,k} by combining the consensus signal with a local gradient descent (computed in parallel with transmission and reception), followed by a projection onto 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W}, yielding the NCOTA-DGD update

𝐰i,k+1=Π​[𝐰i,k+γ​𝐝i,k−η​∇fi​(𝐰i,k)],subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘1Πdelimited-[]subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘𝛾subscript𝐝𝑖𝑘𝜂∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{i,k+1}=\Pi[\mathbf{w}_{i,k}+\gamma{\mathbf{d}}_{i,k}-\eta\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i,k})], (11)

where γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 and η>0𝜂0\eta>0 are consensus and learning stepsizes, respectively. As shown in Sec. III, these need to be chosen suitably, in order to mitigate the impact of fading and noise. The projection operator Π​[𝐚]Πdelimited-[]𝐚\Pi[\mathbf{a}] onto the sphere 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} is defined as

Π​[𝐚]=arg⁡min𝐰∈𝒲⁡‖𝐰−𝐚‖={𝐚if ​‖𝐚‖≤R,R‖𝐚‖​𝐚otherwise,Πdelimited-[]𝐚subscript𝐰𝒲norm𝐰𝐚cases𝐚if norm𝐚𝑅𝑅norm𝐚𝐚otherwise\Pi[\mathbf{a}]=\arg\min_{\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W}}\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{a}\|=\begin{cases}\mathbf{a}&\text{if }\|\mathbf{a}\|\leq R,\\ \frac{R}{\|\mathbf{a}\|}\mathbf{a}&\text{otherwise},\\ \end{cases}

and guarantees that 𝐰i,k∈𝒲,∀i,∀ksubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘𝒲for-all𝑖for-all𝑘\mathbf{w}_{i,k}\in\mathcal{W},\forall i,\forall k. The process described in Sec. II-A to Sec. II-D is then repeated in frame k+1𝑘1k+1 with the new local optimization variable 𝐰i,k+1subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘1\mathbf{w}_{i,k+1}, and so on. A sketch of the overall NCOTA-DGD algorithm is shown below:

We now express NCOTA-DGD  as a noisy version of DGD in (1). Let ϵi,k=𝐝i,k−𝔼​[𝐝i,k|ℱk]subscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖𝑘subscript𝐝𝑖𝑘𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝐝𝑖𝑘subscriptℱ𝑘\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i,k}={\mathbf{d}}_{i,k}-\mathbb{E}[{\mathbf{d}}_{i,k}|\mathcal{F}_{k}] be the error due to fading and noise. Using (9), we can then rewrite (11) as

𝐰i,k+1=Π[\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{i,k+1}=\Pi\Big{[} 𝐰i,k+γ​Λ∗​∑j=1Nωi,j​(𝐰j,k−𝐰i,k)subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘𝛾superscriptΛsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝜔𝑖𝑗subscript𝐰𝑗𝑘subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\displaystyle{\mathbf{w}}_{i,k}+\gamma\Lambda^{*}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\omega_{i,j}(\mathbf{w}_{j,k}-{\mathbf{w}}_{i,k})
−η∇fi(𝐰i,k)+γϵi,k].\displaystyle-\eta\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i,k})+\gamma\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i,k}\Big{]}. (12)

A few observations are in order:

  1. 1.

    The mixing weights satisfy ωi,j≥0,∀i,jsubscript𝜔𝑖𝑗0for-all𝑖𝑗\omega_{i,j}\geq 0,\forall i,j and ωi,j=ωj,isubscript𝜔𝑖𝑗subscript𝜔𝑗𝑖\omega_{i,j}=\omega_{j,i}, since Λi,j=Λj,isubscriptΛ𝑖𝑗subscriptΛ𝑗𝑖\Lambda_{i,j}=\Lambda_{j,i} (channel reciprocity) and {j∈𝒩i}⇔{i∈𝒩j}⇔𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖𝑖subscript𝒩𝑗\{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}\}\Leftrightarrow\{i\in\mathcal{N}_{j}\}. Hence, [𝛀]i,j≜ωi,j≜subscriptdelimited-[]𝛀𝑖𝑗subscript𝜔𝑖𝑗[\boldsymbol{\Omega}]_{i,j}\triangleq\omega_{i,j} is a symmetric, doubly-stochastic mixing matrix (as commonly assumed in consensus-based optimization [5]) induced by the large-scale propagation conditions of the channel.

  2. 2.

    When γ=(Λ∗)−1𝛾superscriptsuperscriptΛ1\gamma{=}(\Lambda^{*})^{-1}, ϵi,k=𝟎subscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖𝑘0\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i,k}{=}\mathbf{0}, and neglecting the projection operation, (II-D) reduces to the DGD updates (1). Hence, NCOTA-DGD can be interpreted as a projected DGD with noisy consensus. The consensus stepsize γ𝛾\gamma helps mitigate the detrimental effect of error propagation due to noise and fading. Remarkably, unlike (1), no explicit knowledge of the mixing weights is required in NCOTA-DGD.

Since each frame includes 222 slots, and in each slot M=d+1𝑀𝑑1M{=}d{+}1 samples are transmitted, the frame duration of NCOTA-DGD is T=2​(d+1)Wt​o​t𝑇2𝑑1subscript𝑊𝑡𝑜𝑡T=\frac{2(d+1)}{W_{tot}}, where Wt​o​tsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑜𝑡W_{tot} is the bandwidth of the system.

III Convergence Analysis

Let 𝐖k=∑i=1N𝐞i⊗𝐰i,ksubscript𝐖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁tensor-productsubscript𝐞𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\mathbf{W}_{k}=\sum_{i=1}^{N}\mathbf{e}_{i}\otimes\mathbf{w}_{i,k} be the 𝐰i,ksubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\mathbf{w}_{i,k}-signals stacked over the network; similarly, let ϵk=∑i=1N𝐞i⊗ϵi,ksubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁tensor-productsubscript𝐞𝑖subscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖𝑘\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{k}=\sum_{i=1}^{N}\mathbf{e}_{i}\otimes\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i,k} be the error signals due to fading and noise, stacked over the network. Let

f​(𝐖)=∑i=1Nfi​(𝐰i)​ and ​𝛀^=𝛀⊗𝐈d.𝑓𝐖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖 and ^𝛀tensor-product𝛀subscript𝐈𝑑\displaystyle f(\mathbf{W})=\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i})\text{ and }\hat{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}=\boldsymbol{\Omega}\otimes\mathbf{I}_{d}.

We then stack the updates (II-D) as

𝐖k+1=ΠN[\displaystyle\mathbf{W}_{k+1}{=}\Pi^{N}\Big{[} 𝐖k+γΛ∗(𝛀^−𝐈N​d)𝐖k−η∇f(𝐖k)+γϵk],\displaystyle{\mathbf{W}}_{k}{+}\gamma\Lambda^{*}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}-\mathbf{I}_{Nd}){\mathbf{W}}_{k}-\eta\nabla f(\mathbf{W}_{k})+\gamma\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{k}\Big{]},

where ΠN​[𝐀]=arg⁡min𝐖∈𝒲N⁡‖𝐖−𝐀‖superscriptΠ𝑁delimited-[]𝐀subscript𝐖superscript𝒲𝑁norm𝐖𝐀\Pi^{N}[\mathbf{A}]=\arg\min_{\mathbf{W}\in\mathcal{W}^{N}}\|\mathbf{W}-\mathbf{A}\| is the projection operator, stacked over the network. Similarly to [5] for the analysis of DGD, we interpret this update as a noisy centralized projected gradient descent step with stepsize η𝜂\eta (see (13)), based on the Lyapunov function

G​(𝐖)≜f​(𝐖)+γ​Λ∗2​η​𝐖⊤​(𝐈N​d−𝛀^)​𝐖,≜𝐺𝐖𝑓𝐖𝛾superscriptΛ2𝜂superscript𝐖topsubscript𝐈𝑁𝑑^𝛀𝐖\displaystyle G(\mathbf{W})\triangleq f(\mathbf{W})+\frac{\gamma\Lambda^{*}}{2\eta}{\mathbf{W}}^{\top}(\mathbf{I}_{Nd}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}){\mathbf{W}},

where the second term incentivizes consensus (in fact, it equals zero when 𝐰i=𝐰j,∀i,jsubscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝐰𝑗for-all𝑖𝑗\mathbf{w}_{i}=\mathbf{w}_{j},\forall i,j). We can then rewrite

𝐖k+1=ΠN​[𝐖k−η​∇G​(𝐖k)+γ​ϵk].subscript𝐖𝑘1superscriptΠ𝑁delimited-[]subscript𝐖𝑘𝜂∇𝐺subscript𝐖𝑘𝛾subscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{W}_{k+1}=\Pi^{N}[\mathbf{W}_{k}-\eta\nabla G(\mathbf{W}_{k})+\gamma\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{k}]. (13)

We study the convergence of NCOTA-DGD under the following standard assumptions.

Assumption 1.

fi​(𝐰)subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰f_{i}(\mathbf{w}) are μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex and L𝐿L-smooth.

Assumption 2.

ζ≜R−‖𝐰∗‖>0≜𝜁𝑅normsuperscript𝐰0\zeta{\triangleq}R{-}\|\mathbf{w}^{*}\|>0 (𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} is in the interior of 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W}).

Since 𝛀𝛀\boldsymbol{\Omega} is symmetric and doubly-stochastic, its eigenvalues (ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i} for the i𝑖ith one) are real-valued and 1=ρ1≥ρ2≥…≥ρN≥−11subscript𝜌1subscript𝜌2…subscript𝜌𝑁11{=}\rho_{1}{\geq}\rho_{2}{\geq}{\dots}{\geq}\rho_{N}\geq-1. We make the following standard assumption on ρ2subscript𝜌2\rho_{2}.

Assumption 3.

ρ2<1.subscript𝜌21\rho_{2}<1.

We are now ready to present the convergence properties of NCOTA-DGD. The main idea is to decompose the error between the local optimization variables and the global optimum into: 1) the error between 𝐖ksubscript𝐖𝑘\mathbf{W}_{k} and the minimizer of the Lyapunov function G𝐺G, defined as

𝐖(G)=arg⁡min𝐖∈𝒲N⁡G​(𝐖);superscript𝐖𝐺subscript𝐖superscript𝒲𝑁𝐺𝐖\displaystyle\mathbf{W}^{(G)}=\arg\min_{\mathbf{W}\in\mathcal{W}^{N}}G(\mathbf{W}); (14)

and 2) the error between the latter and the global optimum 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*}. Accordingly, we bound via the triangle inequality

(𝔼​[1N​∑i=1N‖𝐰i,k−𝐰∗‖2])1/2=1N​‖𝐖k−𝟏⊗𝐰∗‖𝔼superscript𝔼delimited-[]1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘superscript𝐰2121𝑁subscriptnormsubscript𝐖𝑘tensor-product1superscript𝐰𝔼\displaystyle\Big{(}\mathbb{E}\Big{[}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|{\mathbf{w}}_{i,k}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\|^{2}\Big{]}\Big{)}^{1/2}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\|{\mathbf{W}}_{k}-\mathbf{1}\otimes\mathbf{w}^{*}\|_{\mathbb{E}}
≤1N​‖𝐖k−𝐖(G)‖𝔼+1N​‖𝐖(G)−𝟏⊗𝐰∗‖.absent1𝑁subscriptnormsubscript𝐖𝑘superscript𝐖𝐺𝔼1𝑁normsuperscript𝐖𝐺tensor-product1superscript𝐰\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\|{\mathbf{W}}_{k}-\mathbf{W}^{(G)}\|_{\mathbb{E}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\|\mathbf{W}^{(G)}-\mathbf{1}\otimes\mathbf{w}^{*}\|. (15)

These terms are individually bounded in Theorem 1. A sketch of its proof is provided in the Appendix.

Theorem 1.

Assume: (C1) η​(μ+L)+γ​Λ∗​(1−ρN)≤2𝜂𝜇𝐿𝛾superscriptΛ1subscript𝜌𝑁2\eta(\mu{+}L){+}\gamma\Lambda^{*}(1{-}\rho_{N}){\leq}2; (C2) ηγ≤ζ⋅ZN​∇max𝜂𝛾⋅𝜁𝑍𝑁subscript∇\frac{\eta}{\gamma}{\leq}\frac{\zeta\cdot Z}{\sqrt{N}\nabla_{\max}}, with Z≜(1−ρ2)​Λ∗2​1+L/μ≜𝑍1subscript𝜌2superscriptΛ21𝐿𝜇Z{\triangleq}\frac{(1{-}\rho_{2})\Lambda^{*}}{2\sqrt{1{+}L/\mu}}, ∇max≜max𝑖​‖∇fi​(𝐰∗)‖≜subscript∇𝑖norm∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝐰\nabla_{\max}{\triangleq}\underset{i}{\max}\|\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}^{*})\|. Then,

1N​‖𝐖k−𝐖(G)‖𝔼≤2​R​[2​dμ​(Λ∗+σ2E)​γη+e−μ​η​k],1𝑁subscriptnormsubscript𝐖𝑘superscript𝐖𝐺𝔼2𝑅delimited-[]2𝑑𝜇superscriptΛsuperscript𝜎2𝐸𝛾𝜂superscript𝑒𝜇𝜂𝑘\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\|{\mathbf{W}}_{k}{-}\mathbf{W}^{(G)}\|_{\mathbb{E}}{\leq}2R\Big{[}\frac{\sqrt{2}d}{\sqrt{\mu}}\Big{(}\Lambda^{*}{+}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{E}\Big{)}\frac{\gamma}{\sqrt{\eta}}{+}e^{-\mu\eta k}\Big{]}, (16)
1N​‖𝐖(G)−𝟏⊗𝐰∗‖≤∇maxZ​ηγ.1𝑁normsuperscript𝐖𝐺tensor-product1superscript𝐰subscript∇𝑍𝜂𝛾\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\|\mathbf{W}^{(G)}-\mathbf{1}\otimes\mathbf{w}^{*}\|\leq\frac{\nabla_{\max}}{Z}\frac{\eta}{\gamma}. (17)

To minimize these errors, γ/η𝛾𝜂\gamma/\sqrt{\eta} and η/γ𝜂𝛾\eta/\gamma need both be small, while η𝜂\eta should be large to make e−μ​η​ksuperscript𝑒𝜇𝜂𝑘e^{-\mu\eta k} small, yielding a tradeoff between the tuning of η𝜂\eta and γ𝛾\gamma. To further investigate the convergence properties, let us consider a target timeframe K𝐾K at which the algorithm stops. It appears then reasonable to choose η=a⋅K−x𝜂⋅𝑎superscript𝐾𝑥\eta=a\cdot K^{-x} and γ=b⋅K−y𝛾⋅𝑏superscript𝐾𝑦\gamma=b\cdot K^{-y} for suitable a,b,x,y>0𝑎𝑏𝑥𝑦0a,b,x,y>0. Under this choice, (16)-(17) specialize as

1N​‖𝐖K−𝐖(G)‖𝔼≤2​R​[Λ∗+σ2Ea​μ​2​d​b​Kx2−y+e−μ​a⋅K1−x],1𝑁subscriptnormsubscript𝐖𝐾superscript𝐖𝐺𝔼2𝑅delimited-[]superscriptΛsuperscript𝜎2𝐸𝑎𝜇2𝑑𝑏superscript𝐾𝑥2𝑦superscript𝑒⋅𝜇𝑎superscript𝐾1𝑥\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\|{\mathbf{W}}_{K}{-}\mathbf{W}^{(G)}\|_{\mathbb{E}}\leq 2R\Big{[}\frac{\Lambda^{*}{+}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{E}}{\sqrt{a\mu}}\sqrt{2}dbK^{\frac{x}{2}-y}{+}e^{-\mu a\cdot K^{1-x}}\Big{]},
1N​‖𝐖(G)−𝟏⊗𝐰∗‖≤∇maxZ​ab​Ky−x.1𝑁normsuperscript𝐖𝐺tensor-product1superscript𝐰subscript∇𝑍𝑎𝑏superscript𝐾𝑦𝑥\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\|\mathbf{W}^{(G)}-\mathbf{1}\otimes\mathbf{w}^{*}\|\leq\frac{\nabla_{\max}}{Z}\frac{a}{b}K^{y-x}.

The exponential term requires x<1𝑥1x{<}1 to converge when K→∞→𝐾K{\to}\infty, while the other two terms are of order 𝒪​(Kmax⁡{y−x,x/2−y})𝒪superscript𝐾𝑦𝑥𝑥2𝑦\mathcal{O}(K^{\max\{y-x,x/2-y\}}). Hence, max⁡{y−x,x/2−y}𝑦𝑥𝑥2𝑦\max\{y-x,x/2-y\} should be minimized subject to x<1𝑥1x<1, yielding the following corollary.

Corollary 1.

Let 0<ϵ<10italic-ϵ10{<}\epsilon{<}1. With η∝K−(1−ϵ)proportional-to𝜂superscript𝐾1italic-ϵ\eta{\propto}K^{-(1-\epsilon)} and γ∝K−3/4​(1−ϵ)proportional-to𝛾superscript𝐾341italic-ϵ\gamma{\propto}K^{-3/4(1-\epsilon)}, we have e−μ​a⋅Kϵ=𝒪​(K−1/4​(1−ϵ))superscript𝑒⋅𝜇𝑎superscript𝐾italic-ϵ𝒪superscript𝐾141italic-ϵe^{-\mu a\cdot K^{\epsilon}}{=}\mathcal{O}(K^{-1/4(1-\epsilon)}) and

(𝔼​[1N​∑i=1N‖𝐰i,k−𝐰∗‖2])1/2=𝒪​(K−1/4​(1−ϵ)).superscript𝔼delimited-[]1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘superscript𝐰212𝒪superscript𝐾141italic-ϵ\Big{(}\mathbb{E}\Big{[}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|{\mathbf{w}}_{i,k}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\|^{2}\Big{]}\Big{)}^{1/2}=\mathcal{O}(K^{-1/4(1-\epsilon)}).

When ϵ→0→italic-ϵ0\epsilon\to 0, we can see that the error scales as 𝒪​(K−1/4)𝒪superscript𝐾14\mathcal{O}(K^{-1/4}), which is also validated numerically in the next section.

IV Numerical Results

We solve the ’0 versus 1’ task based on the MNIST dataset [16]: the goal is to distinguish images of digits ’0’ and ’1’.

Network deployment: We consider N=200𝑁200N{=}200 nodes, spread uniformly at random over a region of 333km radius. The nodes communicate over a bandwidth of Wt​o​t=subscript𝑊𝑡𝑜𝑡absentW_{tot}{=}1MHz, carrier frequency fc=3subscript𝑓𝑐3f_{c}=3GHz, with a fixed transmission power of Pt​x=5subscript𝑃𝑡𝑥5P_{tx}=5dBm. The noise power spectral density at the receivers is N0=−169subscript𝑁0169N_{0}=-169dBmW/Hz. The average pathloss Λi,jsubscriptΛ𝑖𝑗\Lambda_{i,j} between node i𝑖i and j𝑗j follows Friis’ free space equation.

Data deployment: Each node has a local dataset with a single 28x28 pixels image: 100 nodes have digit ’0’, the remainder have digit ’1’. Node i𝑖i’s image is converted into a 50-dimensional real feature vector 𝐝isubscript𝐝𝑖\mathbf{d}_{i}, representing the components (out of a total of 28×28=784282878428\times 28=784) with largest mean energy across the dataset, and then normalized to ‖𝐝i‖=1normsubscript𝐝𝑖1\|\mathbf{d}_{i}\|=1. We define the label ℓi=1subscriptℓ𝑖1\ell_{i}{=}1 if node i𝑖i’s image is of digit 0, otherwise ℓi=−1subscriptℓ𝑖1\ell_{i}{=}-1.

Optimization problem formulation: We solve the task via regularized logistic regression, with loss function

fi​(𝐰)=0.012​‖𝐰‖2+ln⁡(1+exp⁡{−ℓi⋅𝐝i⊤​𝐰}),subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰0.012superscriptnorm𝐰21⋅subscriptℓ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐝𝑖top𝐰\displaystyle f_{i}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{0.01}{2}\|\mathbf{w}\|^{2}+\ln\left(1+\exp\{-\ell_{i}\cdot\mathbf{d}_{i}^{\top}\mathbf{w}\}\right), (18)

where 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is a d=50𝑑50d=50-dimensional parameter vector. It can be shown that fi​(𝐰)subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰f_{i}(\mathbf{w}), hence the global function F​(𝐰)=1N​∑i=1Nfi​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰F(\mathbf{w}){=}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(\mathbf{w}), are all strongly-convex with parameter μ=0.01𝜇0.01\mu{=}0.01, and smooth with parameter L=μ+1/4𝐿𝜇14L=\mu+1/4.

Wireless distributed optimization algorithms: We implement the following algorithms, all initialized as 𝐰i,0=𝟎,∀isubscript𝐰𝑖00for-all𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i,0}=\mathbf{0},\forall i.

∙∙\bullet NCOTA-DGD (proposed): To enforce half-duplex constraints, 100 nodes, selected randomly, transmit in slot one, the others transmit in slot two. The frame duration is T=102​μ𝑇102𝜇T=102\mus.

We also compare the proposed NCOTA-DGD with implementations of DGD over orthogonal digital (OD-DGD) and analog (OA-DGD) channels. Both follow the updates

𝐰i,k+1subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘1\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{i,k+1} =Π​[𝐜i,k−η​∇fi​(𝐰i,k)],absentΠdelimited-[]subscript𝐜𝑖𝑘𝜂∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\displaystyle=\Pi[\mathbf{c}_{i,k}-\eta\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i,k})], (19)

∙∙\bullet Orthogonal Digital DGD (OD-DGD): each node scales 𝐰i,ksubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\mathbf{w}_{i,k} by the largest magnitude of its components, ‖𝐰i,k‖∞subscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\|\mathbf{w}_{i,k}\|_{\infty}; each component of 𝐰i,k/‖𝐰i,k‖∞subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘subscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\mathbf{w}_{i,k}/\|\mathbf{w}_{i,k}\|_{\infty} (each ∈[−1,1]absent11\in[-1,1]) is then quantized using 9 quantization levels uniformly spaced in the interval [−1,1]11[-1,1]. We use dithered quantization: letting 𝐰^i,ksubscript^𝐰𝑖𝑘\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{i,k} be the quantized signal, it is such that 𝔼​[𝐰^i,k|𝐰i,k]=𝐰i,k𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscript^𝐰𝑖𝑘subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\mathbb{E}[\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{i,k}|{\mathbf{w}}_{i,k}]={\mathbf{w}}_{i,k}. With ‖𝐰i,k‖∞subscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\|\mathbf{w}_{i,k}\|_{\infty} encoded using machine precision (64 bits), the data payload is thus L=64+d​log2⁡(9)≈223𝐿64𝑑subscript29223L=64+d\log_{2}(9)\approx 223bits to encode the d𝑑d-dimensional signal 𝐰i,ksubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\mathbf{w}_{i,k}. Such payload is then transmitted by each node over orthogonal channels (via TDMA), using capacity achieving codes with rate R𝑅R. With the fading channel hi,jk∼𝒞​𝒩​(0,Λi,j)similar-tosuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑗𝑘𝒞𝒩0subscriptΛ𝑖𝑗h_{i,j}^{k}\sim\mathcal{CN}(0,\Lambda_{i,j}) between transmitting node j𝑗j and receiving node i𝑖i, and assuming CSI at the receiver, the probability of successful decoding is Pi,js​u​c​c≜exp⁡{−σ2E​Λi,j​(2R−1)}≜superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑗𝑠𝑢𝑐𝑐superscript𝜎2𝐸subscriptΛ𝑖𝑗superscript2𝑅1P_{i,j}^{succ}{\triangleq}\exp\{-\frac{\sigma^{2}}{E\Lambda_{i,j}}(2^{R}-1)\}. so that signals are mixed proportionally to the average pathloss. Note that OD-DGD requires CSI at the receiver and knowledge of Ps​u​c​csuperscript𝑃𝑠𝑢𝑐𝑐P^{succ}; OA-DGD requires knowledge of the average pathloss Λi,jsubscriptΛ𝑖𝑗\Lambda_{i,j}. In this simulation, we idealistically assume that such information is available at no cost. In contrast, the proposed NCOTA-DGD does not require such knowledge.

Evaluations and Discussion: We evaluate: (1) the optimality error 𝔼^​[1N​∑i=1N‖𝐰i,k−𝐰∗‖2]^𝔼delimited-[]1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘superscript𝐰2\sqrt{\hat{\mathbb{E}}[\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|\mathbf{w}_{i,k}{-}{\mathbf{w}}^{*}\|^{2}]}, measuring the deviation of the local models from the solution of (P) (bounded in expectation in Theorem 1); (2) the average test error TESTk=𝔼^​[1N​∑i=1NTESTi,k]subscriptTEST𝑘^𝔼delimited-[]1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscriptTEST𝑖𝑘\mathrm{TEST}_{k}=\hat{\mathbb{E}}[\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\mathrm{TEST}_{i,k}], where TESTi,ksubscriptTEST𝑖𝑘\mathrm{TEST}_{i,k} is the test error for node i𝑖i at frame k𝑘k. This is computed on a test set of 100 ’0’s and 100 ’1’s; the label associated to feature vector 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d} is predicted as ’0’ if 𝐰i,k⊤​𝐝>0superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘top𝐝0\mathbf{w}_{i,k}^{\top}\mathbf{d}{>}0, and ’1’ otherwise. Here, 𝔼^​[⋅]^𝔼delimited-[]⋅\hat{\mathbb{E}}[\cdot] denotes a sample average of 10 trajectories generated by the algorithms, over independent realizations of fading and noise.

In Fig. 1(a), we plot the best optimality error vis-à-vis running time: all algorithms are evaluated using a set of fixed stepsizes; for each time instance in the x𝑥x-axis, we plot only the optimality error evaluated on the best performing stepsize choice at that time. For NCOTA-DGD, we also show the curves for 3 representative stepsize choices. NCOTA-DGD achieves the best performance, followed by OD-DGD and OA-DGD, thanks to its fast updates: during 500ms, NCOTA-DGD performs 490049004900 iterations, versus only 22 of OD-DGD and 93 of OA-DGD, which are both limited by the use of orthogonal channels. Yet, OD-DGD bridges the gap to NCOTA-DGD over time: this is due to its better noise-suppression capabilities–especially beneficial when approaching convergence to 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*}. This behavior suggests that a mixed analog-digital strategy may further improve performance–a study left for future work. OA-DGD performs the worst: it does not enjoy the noise suppression capabilities of OD-DGD, and its updates are 53×53\times slower than NCOTA-DGD. In Fig. 1(b), we plot the test error under the same best stepsize choice, vis-à-vis running time. It follows a similar trend as Fig. 1(a). Both NCOTA-DGD and OD-DGD converge to the test error under the optimal 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*}.

In Fig. 1(c), we plot the best stepsizes η𝜂\eta (first row), γ𝛾\gamma (second row) and best optimality error (third row) of NCOTA-DGD, for two different phases: initial phase, corresponding to the first ∼similar-to\sim5k iterations (500500500ms, left side); asymptotic phase, after 26k iterations (right side). For each phase, we also fit the data points to the theoretical stepsize tuning and convergence behavior found in Corollary 1: solid lines correspond to η∝(K+δ)−1proportional-to𝜂superscript𝐾𝛿1\eta{\propto}(K{+}\delta)^{{-}1}, γ∝(K+δ)−3/4proportional-to𝛾superscript𝐾𝛿34\gamma{\propto}(K{+}\delta)^{{-}3/4} and "Opt. error"∝(K+δ)−1/4proportional-toabsentsuperscript𝐾𝛿14{\propto}(K{+}\delta)^{{-}1/4}, where the scaling factors (∝proportional-to\propto) and δ𝛿\delta are fit to the data points. We note that, in the initial phase, the optimal η𝜂\eta and γ𝛾\gamma do not match the theoretical behavior. In fact, in this regime, the optimality error is dominated by (17), and decreases quicker than 𝒪​(K−1/4)𝒪superscript𝐾14\mathcal{O}(K^{-1/4}) (bottom left). Conversely, in the asymptotic phase, the optimal η𝜂\eta and γ𝛾\gamma more closely match the theoretical scaling, and the optimality error decays as ∝(K+δ)−1/4proportional-toabsentsuperscript𝐾𝛿14{\propto}(K{+}\delta)^{{-}1/4}, as predicted (with δ=4227𝛿4227\delta=4227). This is in line with Corollary 1 when ϵ→0→italic-ϵ0{\epsilon}{\to}0, and corresponds to a regime when both error terms (16)-(17) are equally dominant.

V Conclusions

We presented NCOTA-DGD, an implementation of DGD that combines local gradient descent with a novel Non-Coherent Over-The-Air consensus scheme to solve distributed machine-learning problems over wirelessly-connected systems. NCOTA-DGD  enables simultaneous transmissions by mapping local optimization signals to a mixture of preamble sequences, and consensus by correlating the received signals with the preamble sequences via non-coherent combining, without explicit knowledge of the mixing weights, nor channel state information. We proved its convergence properties, both theoretically and numerically, and showed superior performance than implementations of DGD over digital and analog orthogonal channels.

Since 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} is at distance ζ𝜁\zeta from the boundary of 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} (Assumption 2), it suffices to show that 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} is closer to 𝐰^isubscript^𝐰𝑖\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{i} than to the boundary of 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W}, i.e. ‖𝐰^i−𝐰∗‖≤ζ,∀inormsubscript^𝐰𝑖superscript𝐰𝜁for-all𝑖\|\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{i}{-}\mathbf{w}^{*}\|{\leq}\zeta,\ \forall i. Lemma 1.

‖ϵk‖𝔼|ℱk2≤8​N​[R​d​(Λ∗+σ2/E)]2≜Σ.superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑘conditional𝔼subscriptℱ𝑘28𝑁superscriptdelimited-[]𝑅𝑑superscriptΛsuperscript𝜎2𝐸2≜Σ\|\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{k}\|_{\mathbb{E}|\mathcal{F}_{k}}^{2}\leq 8N[Rd(\Lambda^{*}+\sigma^{2}/E)]^{2}\triangleq\Sigma.

Proof sketch.

Using (8), we rewrite ϵi,ksubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖𝑘\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i,k} as

ϵi,k=∑m=1M(|ri,mk|2−𝔼​[|ri,mk|2|ℱk])​(𝐳m−𝐰i,k).subscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑚𝑘2𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑚𝑘2subscriptℱ𝑘subscript𝐳𝑚subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i,k}=\sum_{m=1}^{M}(|r_{i,m}^{k}|^{2}-\mathbb{E}[|r_{i,m}^{k}|^{2}|\mathcal{F}_{k}])(\mathbf{z}_{m}-{\mathbf{w}_{i,k}}).

Using the triangle inequality, we bound

‖ϵi,k‖𝔼|ℱk≤∑m=1Msd​(|ri,mk|2|ℱk)​‖𝐳m−𝐰i,k‖,subscriptnormsubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖𝑘conditional𝔼subscriptℱ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀sdconditionalsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑚𝑘2subscriptℱ𝑘normsubscript𝐳𝑚subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘\|\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i,k}\|_{\mathbb{E}|\mathcal{F}_{k}}\leq\sum_{m=1}^{M}\mathrm{sd}(|r_{i,m}^{k}|^{2}|\mathcal{F}_{k})\|\mathbf{z}_{m}-{\mathbf{w}_{i,k}}\|,

where sd​(|ri,mk|2|ℱk)sdconditionalsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑚𝑘2subscriptℱ𝑘\mathrm{sd}(|r_{i,m}^{k}|^{2}|\mathcal{F}_{k}) is the standard deviation of |ri,mk|2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑚𝑘2|r_{i,m}^{k}|^{2}, conditional on ℱksubscriptℱ𝑘\mathcal{F}_{k}; since |ri,mk|2|ℱkconditionalsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑚𝑘2subscriptℱ𝑘|r_{i,m}^{k}|^{2}|\mathcal{F}_{k} is exponentially distributed, it equals 𝔼​[|ri,mk|2|ℱk]𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑚𝑘2subscriptℱ𝑘\mathbb{E}[|r_{i,m}^{k}|^{2}|\mathcal{F}_{k}]. Moreover, ‖𝐳m−𝐰i,k‖≤maxm,m′⁡‖𝐳m−𝐳m′‖=8​R​dnormsubscript𝐳𝑚subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘subscript𝑚superscript𝑚′normsubscript𝐳𝑚subscript𝐳superscript𝑚′8𝑅𝑑\|\mathbf{z}_{m}{-}{\mathbf{w}_{i,k}}\|{\leq}\max_{m,m^{\prime}}\|\mathbf{z}_{m}{-}\mathbf{z}_{m^{\prime}}\|{=}\sqrt{8}Rd. Using (7), it then follows ‖ϵi,k‖𝔼|ℱk≤8​R​d​[∑j∈𝒩iΛi,j+σ2E].subscriptnormsubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖𝑘conditional𝔼subscriptℱ𝑘8𝑅𝑑delimited-[]subscript𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖subscriptΛ𝑖𝑗superscript𝜎2𝐸\|\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i,k}\|_{\mathbb{E}|\mathcal{F}_{k}}{\leq}\sqrt{8}Rd[\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}\Lambda_{i,j}{+}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{E}]. The result directly follows after using ∑j∈𝒩iΛi,j≤Λ∗subscript𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖subscriptΛ𝑖𝑗superscriptΛ\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}\Lambda_{i,j}\leq\Lambda^{*}, squaring both sides and adding over i𝑖i (‖ϵk‖𝔼|ℱk2=∑i=1N‖ϵi,k‖𝔼|ℱk2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑘conditional𝔼subscriptℱ𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖𝑘conditional𝔼subscriptℱ𝑘2\|\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{k}\|_{\mathbb{E}|\mathcal{F}_{k}}^{2}=\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i,k}\|_{\mathbb{E}|\mathcal{F}_{k}}^{2}). ∎
